items.synopsis: A suspected Ponzi scheme that has ensnared Melbourne racing identities and a senior AFL figure was offering returns of up to 8 per cent before the sudden death of its alleged mastermind last month.

title.children: Melbourne lawyer's suspected $100 million Ponzi scheme could dwarf Melissa Caddick fraud

image.altText: soldiers advancing in smoke

items.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says forces have passed the outskirts of Gaza City, while Hezbollah attacks Israeli border positions.

title.children: Israeli troops advance towards Gaza City as Hezbollah attacks in the north

image.altText: A man sits wearing a black had and checkered shirt and glasses and looking into the distance.

items.synopsis: Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs says 65 people, including Australian citizens, permanent residents and their families are still stuck inside Gaza, after 23 managed to flee into Egypt on Wednesday. Follow live.

title.children: 'I had to risk my life': Australian man describes life in Gaza after failing to flee with his wife

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As the death toll in Gaza approaches 10,000, there have been growing calls within the international community for a ceasefire. The US remains formally opposed to that. But White House officials, from the president down, have been talking more and more about their desire to see "pauses" in the war. It's likely to be raised as a priority by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken when he meets Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He's on his way to Israel now. White House national security spokesman John Kirby briefed reporters here in Washington earlier: "We're really not just talking about, like, one pause. "What we're trying to do is explore the idea of as many pauses as might be necessary to continue to get aid out, and to continue to work to get people out safely, including hostages. "The president already worked on one such pause when we were able to get those two Americans out. And that's what we're kind of looking at." On Wednesday (local time), Joe Biden voiced support for a humanitarian pause after a protester interrupted a speech he was giving in Minnesota. “As a rabbi, I need you to call for a ceasefire right now," yelled the protester, who later identified herself to reporters as Rabbi Jessica Rosenberg from the anti-Zionist Jewish Voice for Peace group. "I think we need a pause," Biden replied, according to a pool reporter at the event. "A pause means give time to get the prisoners out." Yesterday, Foreign Minister Penny Wong reiterated Australia's call for humanitarian pauses .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The White House's push for 'pause'

children.content: As the death toll in Gaza approaches 10,000, there have been growing calls within the international community for a ceasefire.
The US remains formally opposed to that. But White House officials, from the president down, have been talking more and more about their desire to see "pauses" in the war.
It's likely to be raised as a priority by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken when he meets Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He's on his way to Israel now.
White House national security spokesman John Kirby briefed reporters here in Washington earlier:
"We're really not just talking about, like, one pause.
"What we're trying to do is explore the idea of as many pauses as might be necessary to continue to get aid out, and to continue to work to get people out safely, including hostages.
"The president already worked on one such pause when we were able to get those
two Americans out
. And that's what we're kind of looking at."

props.alt: John Kirby speaks and gestures with his hand, standing in the White House press room.

children.content: John Kirby at a White House press conference earlier today.
(AP: Evan Vucci)
On Wednesday (local time), Joe Biden voiced support for a humanitarian pause after a protester interrupted a speech he was giving in Minnesota.

“As a rabbi, I need you to call for a ceasefire right now," yelled the protester, who later identified herself to reporters as Rabbi Jessica Rosenberg from the anti-Zionist Jewish Voice for Peace group.
"I think we need a pause," Biden replied, according to a pool reporter at the event. "A pause means give time to get the prisoners out."
Yesterday, Foreign Minister
Penny Wong reiterated Australia's call for humanitarian pauses

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: No more Australians have been evacuated from Gaza today, according to border staff at Egypt's Rafah crossing. Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs (DFAT) says 65 people including Australian citizens, permanent residents and their families are still stuck inside Gaza, after 23 managed to flee into Egypt on Wednesday (local time). Two of the people still stuck inside Gaza are Abdullah Dahlan and his wife Samah. Abdullah went to the border crossing on Wednesday but decided to go back into Gaza when Egyptian officials wouldn't let his wife leave. She's a Palestinian with a visa for Australia, but officials said she had to stay. ABC staff visited Abdullah and Samah inside Gaza today. He told us he thought he was going to die trying to escape. "I had to risk my life going to the border," he says. "I had to find a way of transport, someone to drive me there. And in these circumstances, they don't want to go because they're scared. "Bombing is everywhere, rockets falling over your head, warplanes, they never stop. "It was very frightening yesterday, but I had to do it because I wanted to get out." Abdallah says his time in Gaza during the war has been a nightmare and he doesn't know if he'll ever return. "After what I've seen, I don't know, I'm really not sure," he says. "It's horrible what I see here, it's dreadful, something that can't be described. "You only have to look at the streets. People are everywhere looking for a piece of bread, they want water, [there's] no electricity, no fuel," he says. "Children are suffering so much, it's heartbreaking. You can't get milk for them. "If you just look the streets, people sleep in the streets." Foreign Minister Penny Wong has said it could take some weeks to have all Australians evacuated.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trying — and failing — to flee Gaza holds its own unique terrors

children.content: No more Australians have been evacuated from Gaza today, according to border staff at Egypt's Rafah crossing.

Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs (DFAT) says 65 people including Australian citizens, permanent residents and their families are still stuck inside Gaza, after 23 managed to flee into Egypt on Wednesday (local time).
Two of the people still stuck inside Gaza are Abdullah Dahlan and his wife Samah.

props.alt: A woman in a headscarf makes a coffee

children.content: Samah holds an Australian visa but was blocked from leaving Gaza.
(ABC News )
Abdullah went to the border crossing on Wednesday but decided to go back into Gaza when Egyptian officials wouldn't let his wife leave.
She's a Palestinian with a visa for Australia, but officials said she had to stay.
ABC staff visited Abdullah and Samah inside Gaza today.
He told us he thought he was going to die trying to escape.
"I had to risk my life going to the border," he says.
"I had to find a way of transport, someone to drive me there. And in these circumstances, they don't want to go because they're scared.
"Bombing is everywhere, rockets falling over your head, warplanes, they never stop.
"It was very frightening yesterday, but I had to do it because I wanted to get out."

props.alt: An older man in a cap

children.content: Abdullah decided to stay in Gaza with his wife, rather than leave her behind.
(ABC News)
Abdallah says his time in Gaza during the war has been a nightmare and he doesn't know if he'll ever return.
"After what I've seen, I don't know, I'm really not sure," he says.
"It's horrible what I see here, it's dreadful, something that can't be described.
"You only have to look at the streets. People are everywhere looking for a piece of bread, they want water, [there's] no electricity, no fuel," he says.
"Children are suffering so much, it's heartbreaking. You can't get milk for them.
"If you just look the streets, people sleep in the streets."
Foreign Minister Penny Wong has said it could take some weeks to have all Australians evacuated.

title.children: A monster eddy current is spinning into existence off the coast of Sydney — and it could be trouble
